text:
On http://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.0/mod/mod_access.html#order , the section
under "Ordering is one of:" seems to be backwards.  The description of
Allow,Deny belongs to Deny,Allow and vice versa.

I finally decided that was the case after reading the table and examples below
the descriptions and also looking at the documentation for versions 1.3 and 2.2,
which appear to be correct.

These are indeed correct, there is no issue with the descriptions.

Cheers,
Tony
creator: tony@pc-tony.com
dmeuleman@defiance.edu
text:
If you say that is correct, I will accept it.  You are the experts, after all. 
But I must question why the descriptions are exactly backwards from the
documentation for versions 1.3 and 2.2.

Compare the following:
http://httpd.apache.org/docs/1.3/mod/mod_access.html#order
http://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.0/mod/mod_access.html#order
http://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.2/mod/mod_authz_host.html#order 

When I read that, the definitions for "allow,deny" vs "deny,allow" switch from
1.3 to 2.0 and back for 2.2.  I find that highly suspect, especially since my
2.0 server behaves the way the other documentation describes.

creator: tony@pc-tony.com
text:
Hi,

Are you referring to the paragrpahs:

Deny,Allow
    First, all Allow directives are evaluated; at least one must match, or the
request is rejected. Next, all Deny directives are evaluated. If any matches,
the request is rejected. Last, any requests which do not match an Allow or a
Deny directive are denied by default.
Allow,Deny
    First, all Deny directives are evaluated; if any match, the request is
denied unless it also matches an Allow directive. Any requests which do not
match any Allow or Deny directives are permitted.

??

As these are identical in 2.0 and 2.2

Yes, the paragraphs are identical, but the headings are switched.

You copied the text from the 2.0 docs.  Here is the text from the 2.2 docs. 
Note that the Allow,Deny and Deny,Allow are the headings for the opposite paragraph.

Allow,Deny
    First, all Allow directives are evaluated; at least one must match, or the
request is rejected. Next, all Deny directives are evaluated. If any matches,
the request is rejected. Last, any requests which do not match an Allow or a
Deny directive are denied by default.
Deny,Allow
    First, all Deny directives are evaluated; if any match, the request is
denied unless it also matches an Allow directive. Any requests which do not
match any Allow or Deny directives are permitted.
